hints.content:
Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.

We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

Let's take a look at how Joe broke apart the numbers to multiply.

options.explanation:
$542\times6$

We can break apart $542$ into $500 + 40 + 2$ and multiply each part by $6$.

We can start by multiplying $500\times6$ , $40\times6$, or $2\times6$. The order does not matter since we will be adding all the products together.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&\begin{align}
542&\\
\underline{{} \times 6}\end{align}\\
\text{any order}&\left\{\begin{align}
3{,}000\\
240\\
\underline{{}+12}\end{align}\right.\\
&3{,}252
\end{array}$
options.showPrompt: Can you show me an example please?

hints.content:
###Step $1$

$\begin{align}
61\blueE{2}&\\
\underline{{} \times \blueE{8}}&\\
\blueE{16}&\quad \blueE{8} \times \blueE{2}
\end{align}$

There are $2$ ones in $612$, and $\blueE8\times\blueE2=\blueE{16}$. So Joe did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$

$\begin{align}
6\purpleE{1}2&\\
\underline{{} \times \purpleE{8}}&\\
16&\quad {8} \times {2} \\
{{}\purpleE{80}}&\quad \purpleE{8} \times \purpleE{10}
\end{align}$

There is $1$ ten in $612$, and $\purpleE8\times\purpleE{10}=\purpleE{80}$. So Joe did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$

$\begin{align}
\maroonE612&\\
\underline{{} \times \maroonE2}&\\
{16}&\qquad{8\times 2}\\
{80}&\qquad {8} \times 10\\
\underline{{}+\maroonE{4{,}800}}&\qquad\maroonE{8\times 600}
\end{align}$

Joe said that there were $6$ tens, not $6$ hundreds, in $\maroonE{6}12$. So Joe made a mistake in step $3$.
Joe made a mistake in step $3$.

question.content:
Joe tried to evaluate $612\times8$ using partial products, but he made a mistake.  His work is below.

$
\begin{align}
&&612 \\
&&\underline{\times\phantom{22}8} \\
&\blueE{\text{Step 1}}\quad&\blueE{16}&\qquad\blueE{8\times2}\\
&\purpleE{\text{Step 2}}&\purpleE{{}\phantom{2} 80} &\qquad\purpleE{8\times 10}\\
&\maroonE{\text{Step 3}}&\underline\maroonE{+\phantom{2}{480}}&\qquad\maroonE{8\times 60}\\
&\goldE{\text{Step 4}}&\goldE{576}& &
 \end{align}$

**Find Joe's mistake.**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: There are $2$ ones in $612$, and $\blueE8\times\blueE2=\blueE{16}$. So Joe did not make a mistake in step $1$.
There is $1$ ten in $612$, and $\purpleE8\times\purpleE{10}=\purpleE{80}$. So Joe did not make a mistake in step $2$.
There are $6$ hundreds, not $6$ tens, in $612$. So Joe made a mistake in step $3$.
Joe correctly added his three partial products.
